A Transformer layer is the foundational building block of transformer models (e.g., BERT, RoBERTa, CamemBERT). It consists of multiple subcomponents that work together to process and transform an input sequence into a richer, context-aware representation. Here's a detailed breakdown:

High-Level Structure of a Transformer Layer

  1. Multi-Head Self-Attention:

    • Captures relationships between tokens in the sequence.
    • Computes a weighted combination of all tokens for each token.

  2. Add & Norm (Residual Connection + Layer Normalization):

    • Adds the original input to the attention output.
    • Applies normalization for stable learning.

  3. Feedforward Neural Network (FFN):

    • Applies two linear layers with an activation function to transform the attention output.

  4. Add & Norm (Residual Connection + Layer Normalization):

    • Adds the input from the attention output to the FFN output.
    • Normalizes again.

Step-by-Step Breakdown

1. Input to the Layer

  • Input is a matrix of token embeddings: X∈Rn×dX \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times d}X∈Rn×d, where:
    • nnn: Sequence length (number of tokens).
    • ddd: Embedding size (dimensionality of each token vector).

2. Multi-Head Self-Attention

The purpose of self-attention is to compute context-aware representations by relating every token to every other token in the sequence.

Key Steps:

  1. Linear Transformations:

    • Each token is linearly transformed into three vectors:
      • Query (QQQ): What does this token want to know?
      • Key (KKK): What information does this token offer?
      • Value (VVV): The actual content of the token.
    • For each token xxx:
      Q=XWQ,K=XWK,V=XWVQ = XW^Q, \quad K = XW^K, \quad V = XW^VQ=XWQ,K=XWK,V=XWV
      • WQ,WK,WVW^Q, W^K, W^VWQ,WK,WV are learnable weight matrices of size d×dkd \times d_kd×dk​, where dk=d/hd_k = d / hdk​=d/h (hhh is the number of attention heads).

  2. Attention Scores:

    • Compute attention scores by comparing QQQ and KKK:
      Attention(Q,K)=QKTdk\text{Attention}(Q, K) = \frac{QK^T}{\sqrt{d_k}}Attention(Q,K)=dk​​QKT​
      • This is a scaled dot product. Dividing by dk\sqrt{d_k}dk​​ stabilizes gradients.

  3. Softmax:

    • Apply the softmax function to normalize the attention scores into probabilities:
      α=softmax(QKTdk)\alpha = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^T}{\sqrt{d_k}}\right)α=softmax(dk​​QKT​)

  4. Weighted Sum:

    • Use the attention probabilities (α\alphaα) to compute a weighted sum of the VVV vectors:
      Output=αV\text{Output} = \alpha VOutput=αV

  5. Multi-Head Attention:

    • Split the embeddings into hhh attention heads and compute attention for each head independently.

    • Concatenate the results from all heads and project them back to the original embedding size using another linear transformation:
      MultiHead(Q,K,V)=Concat(head1,…,headh)WO\text{MultiHead}(Q, K, V) = \text{Concat}(\text{head}_1, \dots, \text{head}_h)W^OMultiHead(Q,K,V)=Concat(head1​,…,headh​)WO

    • WOW^OWO: Learnable projection matrix for combining heads.

Output Shape:

  • The output of multi-head attention has the same shape as the input: n×dn \times dn×d.

3. Add & Norm (Residual Connection + LayerNorm)

  • Add the original input (XXX) to the attention output:
    Y=X+Attention OutputY = X + \text{Attention Output}Y=X+Attention Output
  • Apply layer normalization:
    Norm(Y)=Y−μσ×γ+β\text{Norm}(Y) = \frac{Y - \mu}{\sigma} \times \gamma + \betaNorm(Y)=σY−μ​×γ+β
    • μ,σ\mu, \sigmaμ,σ: Mean and standard deviation of YYY.
    • γ,β\gamma, \betaγ,β: Learnable scaling and shifting parameters.

4. Feedforward Neural Network (FFN)

The FFN is applied independently to each token in the sequence. It consists of:

  1. Linear Transformation (Expand dimensionality):
    Z1=YW1+b1Z_1 = YW_1 + b_1Z1​=YW1​+b1​

    • W1∈Rd×dffW_1 \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d_{ff}}W1​∈Rd×dff​, dffd_{ff}dff​: Intermediate size, typically larger than ddd (e.g., 4x).

  2. Non-Linearity (e.g., GELU or ReLU):
    Z2=GELU(Z1)Z_2 = \text{GELU}(Z_1)Z2​=GELU(Z1​)

  3. Linear Transformation (Project back to original dimensionality):
    Z3=Z2W2+b2Z_3 = Z_2W_2 + b_2Z3​=Z2​W2​+b2​

    • W2∈Rdff×dW_2 \in \mathbb{R}^{d_{ff} \times d}W2​∈Rdff​×d.

Output Shape:

  • n×dn \times dn×d (same as input).

5. Add & Norm (Residual Connection + LayerNorm)

  • Add the input from the attention layer (YYY) to the FFN output:
    Z=Y+Z3Z = Y + Z_3Z=Y+Z3​
  • Apply layer normalization:
    Norm(Z)\text{Norm}(Z)Norm(Z)

Purpose of a Transformer Layer

Problems Solved:

  1. Sequence Modeling:

    • Captures dependencies between all tokens, regardless of distance (unlike RNNs).

  2. Parallelism:

    • Processes the entire sequence at once, allowing efficient training and inference.

  3. Global Context:

    • Self-attention aggregates information from all tokens for each token, creating a contextualized representation.

Challenges Brought:

  1. Computational Complexity:

    • Self-attention has O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) complexity, making it expensive for long sequences.

  2. Memory Usage:

    • Storing attention matrices for large sequences requires significant memory.

Summary of Transformer Layer Steps

  1. Input embeddings (tokens + positions) enter the transformer layer.
  2. Multi-Head Self-Attention computes context-aware token representations.
  3. Add & Norm stabilizes learning with residual connections.
  4. Feedforward Neural Network applies additional transformations.
  5. Add & Norm refines the output.

This layered structure enables powerful, context-aware representations for tasks like language modeling, translation, and more. Let me know if you'd like a practical example or further clarifications!
